ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Due to the synapse-like nonlinearity and memory characteristics, the memristor is often used to simulate the biological neural synapse. In this paper, a family of three-neuron Hopfield neural network (HNN) models based on the variable number memristive self-connected synapses is proposed. Firstly, a single memristive self-connected synapse (SMSCS) HNN model is constructed, which can generate a single direction multi-scroll attractor controlled by the memristor parameters. Meanwhile, its dynamic behaviors including equilibrium points, multiple coexisting attractors and controllable n-scroll chaotic attractors are analyzed. Secondly, based on the above SMSCS HNN model, two types of multiple memristive self-connected synapse (MMSCS) HNN models are constructed. By changing the control parameters of the memristors, these MMSCS HNN models can not only generate the different scroll numbers of grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors, but also can produce the spatial initial-offset coexisting attractors. The above three HNN models utilizing the variable number memristors to simulate one to three self-connected synapses can generate a class of complex chaotic attractors, which include single direction, grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors. Finally, the feasibility of the proposed HNN models is verified by the FPGA platform.

ce:section.ce:para: The biological brain, which is composed of a large number of neurons and synapses, is a highly complex nonlinear system with the chaotic dynamic behaviors [ 1, 2]. We use the brain for thinking, associating, memorizing, and reasoning and more [ 3]. Nowadays, artificial neural networks have received much attention for their design to imitate the structure of the biological brain [ 4–6]. It is known that a large number of neuron models and neural network models have been proposed so far, such as Hodgkin-Huxley (HH) neuron [ 7], Hindmarsh-Rose (HR) neuron [ 8], deep neural network [ 9] and convolutional neural network [ 10], and so on. Among these models, the Hopfield neural network (HNN) has become an important model for studying the biological brain characteristics due to its brain-like network structure and the complex dynamic characteristics [ 11].

Memristor, as the fourth basic electronic element after resistor, capacitor and inductor, is defined by Chua for describing the relationship between charge and magnetic flux [ 12]. In the last twenty years, due to its intrinsic nonlinear characteristics, the memristor has been widely applied to construct memristive chaotic systems to obtain complex dynamic behaviors [ 13–15], such as chaos, hyperchaos, bursting, coexistent bifurcation, etc. In recent years, due to its plasticity and nonvolatility closely related to the memory characteristic of neurons, the memristor is widely employed in the neural networks. On the one hand, the memristor is one of the most suitable components for simulating the strengthening or weakening of synaptic weights. The memristor can be utilized to achieve the changeable connection weight by replacing the resistive connection weight. Numerous memristive neural network (MNN) models based on these strategies have been proposed to exhibit a variety of complex dynamical behaviors [ 16, 17]. For instance, Bao et al. [ 16] proposed a hyperbolic-type memristor based three-neuron HNN to reveal the coexistence of asymmetric attractors, which is achieved through substituting one of resistive coupling-connection weight with a memristive synaptic weight. On the other hand, the memristor has the electrical properties of magnetic flux, which can be used to simulate the neural response to external stimuli, such as electromagnetic radiation or electromagnetic induction current. Many researchers have used the memristors to simulate the effects of electromagnetic radiation on artificial neural networks [ 18–20]. For instance, Hu et al. [ 21] firstly studied a small HNN with three neurons, in which one of the three neurons is exposed to electromagnetic radiation, and the system can appear chaotic motion and periodic motion intermittently. Lin et al. [ 22] found that with the increase of the number of neurons stimulated by electromagnetic radiation, the dynamical behaviors of the HNN will gradually change from period moving to chaos, transient chaos and intricate hyperchaos. More recently, by using a discrete memristor to simulate electromagnetic radiation, Lai et al. [ 23] constructed a discrete neural network which can observe the phenomenon of homogeneous and heterogeneous infinite coexistence attractors. In addition, the electromagnetic induction current induced by the membrane potential difference between neurons in the neural network can also be simulated by memristors to build different MNNs. For instance, Chen et al. [ 24] employed the hyperbolic-type memristor to describe the potential difference between the interconnected neurons, and presented a unified memristive HNN model to simulate the dynamic behavior of electromagnetic induction current. In Reference [ 25], by introducing a memristor-based electromagnetic induction current to substitute the externally applied current in a Morris-Lecar model, the presented system shows the diverse period-adding bifurcations as well as abundant periodic and chaotic burst firings. When considering both electromagnetic radiation and electromagnetic induction current, for example, Wan et al. [ 26] used a quadratic nonlinear memristor and a hyperbolic-type memristor to simulate the influence of electromagnetic radiation and electromagnetic induction current on a simple HNN, and found the coexistence bifurcation phenomena and the coexistence attractors. In short, the versatility of memristors has made them a fascinating topic in neural networks.

Chaotic attractors can be categorized into single-scroll, double-scroll and multi-scroll attractors based on their scroll number. Due to their intricate topological structure and rich ergodic space, the multi-scroll attractors have the potential applications in engineering areas, such as pseudo-random number generator [ 27], medical image encryption and remote sensing image encryption [ 28, 29], which make them more secure and efficient compared to the single-scroll or double-scroll attractors. In the past few years, the multi-scroll attractors are widely studied in the traditional chaotic systems, such as introducing trigonometric functions [ 30] or symbolic functions [ 31], employing fractal methods [ 32, 33], etc. However, the above common methods in the traditional chaotic systems [ 30–33] can ' t be used to construct multi-scroll attractors in the neural networks, since these methods can ' t be biologically explained. At present, only a few papers mentioned the generation of multi-scroll attractors in the neural networks. For example, Zhang et al. [ 34] constructed a non-equilibrium memristive HR neuron, which can generate the multi-scroll hidden attractors with complex topology by changing the internal parameters of memristor. Yu et al. [ 35] proposed a memristive HNN and constructed a novel local active memristor to simulate the synapse connection weight, which can perform the controllable multi-double-scroll chaotic attractors and controllable initial offset boosting coexistence. Additionally, Wan et al. [ 36] designed a memristive HNN under external pulse controlled memristor, pulse current stimulation and their combined effects, which can generate the various multi-scroll chaotic and multi-scroll periodic strange attractors with symmetric structure. In another study, Lai et al. [ 37] introduced the different number of multi-piecewise hyperbolic function into the HNN model, which results in the successful expansion of grid multi-scroll attractors in the different directions. Wan et al. [ 38] proposed a new method to generate the grid multi-scroll attractors in an HNN by integrating the multi-level-logic pulse current and the multi-piecewise memristor into an HNN model. However, most of the above studies have focused on the single direction multi-scroll attractors, and the study of the grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors with higher complexities in the neural networks remains relatively limited. Therefore, the study of the multi-direction expansion of multi-scroll neural networks with the different working mechanism still needs further exploration.

Motivated by the above mentioned considerations, based on a three-neuron HNN, this paper study the dynamic behavior of single direction, grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors in three different cases which utilizing the multi-piecewise memristors to simulate one to three self-connected synapses. The main contributions and characteristics of this paper can be summarized as follows.

1) Firstly, by introducing a multi-piecewise memristor, a new three-neuron HNN model based on a single memristive self-connected synapse (SMSCS) is constructed. The SMSCS HNN model can generate a single direction multi-scroll chaotic attractor controlled by the memristor parameters. The phase diagram, bifurcation diagram and Lyapunov exponent are used to analyze the complex dynamic behaviors, including equilibrium points, multiple coexisting attractors and controllable n-scroll chaotic attractors.

2) Secondly, two types of multiple memristive self-connected synapse (MMSCS) HNN models are constructed. These MMSCS HNN models are implemented on the basis of SMSCS HNN model by adding one or two memristive self-connected synapses, respectively. By changing the control parameters of the memristors, these MMSCS HNN models can not only generate the different scroll numbers of grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors, but also can produce the spatial initial-offset coexisting attractors.

3) Finally, the single direction, grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors along with the spatial initial-offset coexisting attractors are implemented on the FPGA platform, verifying the feasibility of the proposed SMSCS and MMSCS HNN models.

The rest of this paper is arranged as follows. Section 2 introduces the mathematical model of SMSCS HNN and analyzes its complex dynamical characteristics through the numerical methods. Section 3 introduces two types of MMSCS HNNs, focusing on the discussion of grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors along with the spatial initial-offset coexisting behaviors. Section 4 discusses the experimental results with the FPGA platform to verify the numerical results. Section 5 summarizes with a few conclusions.

The theoretical analysis and simulation result of the proposed HNN model usually need to be verified by the hardware implementation. Due to the hyperbolic tangent nonlinearity, the hardware implementation of the HNN model using an analog circuit is extremely complex. Additionally, the spatial initial-offset coexisting behaviors generated by the HNN model are highly dependent on the initial states, but the initial states cannot be pre-set in the analog circuit. However, the digital circuits based on FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) can use the advantages of adders and multipliers, exponential calculators and comparators to precisely control the initial state and time step through software [ 43]. Therefore, this section chooses the FPGA platform to verify the simulation results of the proposed HNN model.

In this section, we utilize the Vivado 2018.3 platform to synthesize the proposed HNN model with the variable number memristive self-connected synapses based on FPGA. First, the proposed continuous-time HNN model was discretized using the high-order Runge-Kutta algorithm. The discrete-time module was programmed using the Verilog Hardware Description Language (VHDL) and implemented on the Xilinx ZYNQ-XC7Z020 board. The discrete time step was set to 0.001. The floating-point calculations were used to obtain the experimental results which are consistent with the simulation results. To accommodate the limitations of the FPGA Xilinx ZYNQ-XC7Z020 board, the floating-point numbers were converted to the 14-bit fixed-point numbers for output.

Fig. 15 shows the experimental setup of the FPGA hardware platform connected to a digital oscilloscope. The bitstream files generated on the workstation were integrated into the FPGA development board, and the dual channel DAC unit can select the output signals of x0_4 and x0_5, or x0_4 and x0_6, or x0_5 and x0_6. Fig. 16 shows the experimental results of single direction multi-scroll attractors in the φ 1- y plane with the different values of N and M, which is consistent with the simulation results as shown in Fig. 5(b), (c) and (d). The controllable number of grid multi-scroll chaotic attractors in the φ 1- φ 2 plane can be observed as shown in Fig. 17 , which is consistent with the simulation results as shown in Fig. 8(a), (b) and (c). The spatial multi-scroll attractors projectioned on different planes can be observed on the oscilloscope, as shown in Fig. 18 , which is consistent with the simulation results as shown in Fig. 12(a), (b) and (c). Furthermore, the coexistence of double-scroll attractors associated with the spatial initial-offset behavior is presented in Fig. 19 , which is consistent with the simulation results as shown in Fig. 14(b). It can be found that the FPGA realization matches exactly with the MATLAB platform, which demonstrates the correctness and feasibility of these multi-scroll attractors across the different type of platforms. Besides, the performance comparison of the proposed multi-direction multi-scroll HNN model with the existing memristor-based neural network is listed in Table 1 , which includes scroll type, scroll number, coexisting attractor type, multi-direction coexisting attractor and hardware implementation.

In this paper, a new method for generating multi-scroll chaotic attractors in HNN with the variable number memristive self-connected synapses is designed. Firstly, the single memristive HNN model is constructed by introducing a multi-piecewise memristor to simulate the self-connected synapse of neuron 2, which can realize the expansion of the multi-scroll attractors in single direction. Secondly, by further introducing the multi-piecewise memristors to simulate the other self-connected synapses of neuron 3 and neuron 1, the double memristive HNN model and the triple memristive HNN model have been constructed, which can realize the grid and spatial multi-scroll attractors respectively. Numerical simulations show that the proposed HNN models can increase the expansion directions of multi-scroll attractors by increasing the number of memristors, and also can generate the spatial initial-offset coexisting attractors by changing the memristor’ initial states. Finally, the experimental results conducted on the FPGA platform successfully confirm the multi-scroll attractors and the spatial initial-offset behavior. In conclusion, these findings provide a valuable insight into the generation mechanism of multi-direction multi-scroll chaotic attractors. However, how to apply these multi-direction multi-scroll chaotic attractors to pseudorandom number generator and image encryption needs further research.
